items.content_html:
Summary

Changes string concatenation to template literals where possible.

I have tried to judge when change is improvement and when it's not and left out change that would not improve code readability.

Some cases where missing spaces between words, which is much easier to spot with template literals.

I also have changed some concatenations used in console logging to instead to use "," to not convert objects to string.

Motivation

Supporting details

Related issues

items.title: MINOR: remove the 3 in CSS

items.content_html:
This is the 2th part for the issue #18780
In this PR I covered these instances:

  1. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/box-flex-group

  2. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/clamp

  3. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/calc

  4. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/image/image

  5. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/var

  6. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/env
    For the env function I used this resource:
    https://docs.w3cub.com/css/env.html

  7. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/max
    For the max function I used this resource:
    https://www.w3schools.com/cssref/func_max.asp

  8. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/-moz-outline-radius
    For the -moz-outline-radius I used this resource:
    https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/css-moz-outline-radius-property/

  9. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/-moz-image-region

items.title: alt text for images updated

items.content_html:
Classical for loops are error-prone (setting the right condition, not mixing indices…) and difficult to read when used to loop on all elements of an Array-like structure.

This PR changes some occurrences to use the modern for…of, or .forEach() in some occurrences.

Note that:

  • I use for…of if I don't need the index
  • I use .forEach() when I do, or on an object where for…of may not work.
  • There were a couple of cases where the loop copied an Array into a new one; I used Array.from() instead.
items.title: Avoid classical for when looping through all items of an Array-like object (part #2)

Classical for loops are error-prone (setting the right condition, not mixing indices…) and difficult to read when used to loop on all elements of an Array-like structure.

This PR changes some occurrences to use the modern for…of, or .forEach() in some occurrences.

Note that:

  • I use for…of if I don't need the index
  • I use .forEach() when I do, or on an object where for…of may not work.
  • There were a couple of cases where the loop copied an Array into a new one; I used Array.from() instead.

items.content_html:
Summary

Replaces the text "January 1, 1970 00:00:00 UTC" on the Date.now() page with a link to the ECMAScript epoch.

Motivation

This allows the reader to easily find more information about the epoch and makes this page consistent with Date.prototype.getTime(). I noticed this inconsistency when I was looking at both pages to see if these functions return the same kind of timestamp and had to click through to the epoch page to be sure that they were referencing the same time.

Supporting details

Related issues

items.title: Link to ECMAScript epoch from Date.now()

items.title: Update index.md to React new version

items.content_html:
How to access

You get the 'Modules' drop-down in the 'Reference' section in the CSS sidebar.

Current status

The 'Modules' pages include more or less the following sections and subsections based on whether or not they are applicable for the page (examples: CSS Images and CSS Display):

- Reference
  - Properties
  - At-rules
  - Functions
  - Data types
- Guides
- Specifications
- Browser compatibility
- See also

The subsections under 'Reference' also match the categories in the CSS sidebar (screenshot below).

  • On some pages, the section title "Properties" is "CSS Properties".
  • On some pages, the section title "Alt-rules" is "CSS Alt-rules".

What this PR fixes

  • Updates the section titles to ensure consistency: "Properties", "Alt-rules", "Data types"
  • Updates casing of page and section titles to follow sentence casing
  • Moves glossary entries and external resources to "See also" section
  • Rewrites some sentences to remove the occurrence of the first person "I"

Question

Should the "Types" drop-down in the sidebar be called "Data types"?

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Fixes titles for consistency and sentence casing

items.content_html:
Summary

Removed backticks from the headings. Made the word "App" lowercase when it is intended to mean the to-do list application itself, and wrapped it in backticks when it refers to the App.vue component. Added missing backticks around a <div> tag. As for the aria-labelledby attribute, it should not be there and its addition to the tag isn't even mentioned. Its addition along with its purpose is described elsewhere later on in the guide.

Motivation

Supporting details
